update.description:
Integrated qwt to create plots. 

  - The axis labels are currently hardcoded. 

  - Y axis will auto-scale but disabled when user zooms/pans with the mouse. 

  - X-axis auto scrolls as new data come in. Window size is set to 10 simulation seconds.

Integrated introspection client in PlotManager to provide `sim_time`. Also added sample data for a few test variables in the palette. 

Things to try:

- add a variable to the y container to create a new plot

- add a variable to another variable (which creates a multi-variable) to see one plot with multiple "plot curves"

- delete a variable to remove the corresponding plot curve

- reset simulation to see new plot curves added to the existing plot

TODOs

- Make plot title and variable labels editable

- Improve user interaction with plot (zoom, pan, etc)
update.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

pull_request.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

content.raw: ahh that's right, got mixed up with supporting different x variables in canvases. All plots within the same canvas shares the same x-axis. I'll make the change

pull_request.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

pullrequest.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

content.raw: Oh ok. I had understood from the design that multiplots within a same canvas would always share the same X axis. Kind of how multi-variable plots do, but in separate spaces so it doesn't get cluttered. In the design, multiplots are touching each other vertically.
content.html: Oh ok. I had understood from the design that multiplots within a same canvas would always share the same X axis. Kind of how multi-variable plots do, but in separate spaces so it doesn't get cluttered. In the design, multiplots are touching each other vertically.

pullrequest.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

content.raw: oh I see. I think we would need to add checks to determine which axis label to show when plots are added/removed. The checks are temporary until we support different x variables. So I'm inclined to leave it as it is for now.
content.html: oh I see. I think we would need to add checks to determine which axis label to show when plots are added/removed. The checks are temporary until we support different x variables. So I'm inclined to leave it as it is for now.

pull_request.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

pullrequest.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

content.raw:
1. Drag Dog to y

1. Drag Cat to y, separate from Dog - a multiplot is created

1. Drag Turtle to Dog - both show on the same multi-variable plot and cat on the other plot

1. Drag Cat to Dog - Cat shows on both the top plot and the bottom plot (the bottom plot should have disappeared)
content.html:
1. Drag Dog to y

  2. Drag Cat to y, separate from Dog - a multiplot is created

  3. Drag Turtle to Dog - both show on the same multi-variable plot and cat on the other plot

  4. Drag Cat to Dog - Cat shows on both the top plot and the bottom plot (the bottom plot should have disappeared)

content.raw:
oh oops I missed the `return` statement in the `if` statement. 

I though `expired` is just a quick way of checking to see if the object is deleted right?
content.html:
oh oops I missed the return statement in the if statement.

I though expired is just a quick way of checking to see if the object is deleted right?

pull_request.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

pullrequest.title: Plot Window: part 3 - Canvas, plot, curve

content.html:
I believe we should use the weak_ptr in this way:

auto c = plotCurve.lock();
if (!c)
{
  gzerr << "Unable to add points. "
        << "Curve with id' " << _id << "' is not found" << std::endl;
  return;
}

c->AddPoints(_pts);

In your current code, expired() might return false (the object is still there), then the object might be destroyed, lock() returns a null pointer and c->AddPoints segfaults. Note the return inside the if too.

It this makes sense, consider it in other places in this class.
